events.name: GDG Oslo December Meetup
events.description:
Note! All seats are now taken, but if you are interested in participating put your name on the waiting list.

 

Schedule:

17:00-17:30:

Food (and more?), kindly sponsored by Google Norway.

Harald Jakob Skaarn from Google gives a short introduction to Google and a brief tour of Google's Norway office.

 

17:30-18:10 - "How to Create and Maintain Large Web Apps in JavaScript" (Peter Svensson, Google Community Manager/Greener Grass Web Design )

Peter Svensson have written large JS apps for several years and will walk through his favorite tips and tricks to get a maintainable codebase and a reactive application.

 

18:10-18:50 - "Test-driven Android Development - Tools and Techniques" (Johan Burrell, EVRY Stockholm - presentation held via Google Hangout)

These days apps have become more and more business centric, long lived through frequent updates and dependent on a number of external frameworks or APIs. Good routines for testing can help reduce development time, find bugs early and make maintenance easy. In this talk, Johan will demonstrate some techniques and tools available for the Android platform that are suitable for both small and big projects.

18:50-19:30 - "Fast, user-friendly and power-efficient network communication on Android" (Erik Hellman, Sony Mobile - presentation held via Google Hangout)

Erik Hellman works as a Research Engineer at Sony Mobile in Lund, Sweden. He has also worked as a lead software architect for the Android development on the Xperia smart phone series.

Designing and implementing an efficient network communication in your Android application is not an easy task. Developers face a difficult balance between latency, power-efficiency, data charges and several other aspects that can be the cause for bad reviews. In this session Sony Mobile will share their experience and lessons learned on how to handle network communication in the most effective way possible. Learn how to be power efficient while still keeping the best possible latency for the end user.

events.name: GDG Oslo - 2013:01 Meetup
events.description:
Schedule:

17:00-17:30

Something to eat and drink, kindly sponsored by Acando.

 

17:30-18:15: Uwe Kubosch - "Ruby on Java on Android"

Android has made great advances the last couple of years, and is one of the major actors in the phone and tablet markets. The main programming language on Android is Java. Android offers a comprehensive API to apps running on the Dalvik VM. The API covers a large part of the Java standard library in addition to Android specific APIs. Android includes tooling to convert Java .class files to Dalvik VM compatible class files. Ruboto uses JRuby to allow you to run Ruby scripts on the Dalvik VM. Using Ruby code, you have access to the complete Android API.

This presentation will introduce the different parts of Ruboto. Come see what Ruboto has to offer.

18:15-19:00: Gaël Pouzerate - "One Million Downloads"

Gaël has developed an app named GreenPower. After two years work and a lot of effort, the app has now been downloaded over 1.2 million times from the Google Play Store.

During this time Android development went from being a hobby activity with a few daily downloads, to quitting his regular job and start working full time on the project.

Gaël has learned a lot of do's and don'ts about how to make an app successful and climb up the charts. In this presentation, he will provide a humble feedback on this journey, and try to bring advices that may be useful for other developers.

events.name: GDG Oslo - 2013:02 Meetup
events.description:
17:00-17:30: Mingling + food

Meet other GDG Oslo members before the presentations start. The Mesh café is open if you would like to buy something to eat and drink before the presentations.

 

<strong style="font-size : medium">17:30-18:15: Tine Kleivane - "Before frameworks: JavaScript basics"

JavaScript is emerging as a major trend, but a lot of developers follow a copy-paste technique when learning and using the language. This presentation covers the basics of JavaScript, from variables and functions to inheritance and classes. We will also see how its asynchronous execution affects us and how we can handle it.

Tine is a developer at Bekk Consulting and is currently working on Java and JavaScript projects. She has a keen interest in JavaScript and fights to keep the spaghetti code at bay. This can and have been done in multiple ways and with a myriad of frameworks, but with the continuous innovation in the JS world there is still much to embrace.

 

18:15-19:00: August Lilleaas - "Introduction to AngularJS"

What is AngularJS all about? Hint: it's not about never writing a single line of JS again and putting all your logic in the HTML templates. How do you write code with it? What does AngularJS provide to solve some of the problems we face when we build stateful and highly asynchronous user interfaces?

August works in Kodemaker as a consultant/contractor, building web systems in many different shapes and sizes. He has been doing web stuff for 10 years, except from a slight (enjoyable) detour into native iOS land.

 

--


Note! This meetup will probably only be of interest to developers, as the topics are technical.

events.name: GDG Oslo - 2013:03 Meetup
events.description:
Android design meetup in cooperation with Mobile Meetup Oslo.

Please join their meetup group for more information about the event, and for registration.

events.name: 2013:04 - Indie Game Development
events.description:
Schedule:

17:00-17:30: Mingling, food and drinks
Kindly sponsored by Acando

17:30-18:15: Jerome Lacoste (WeWantToKnow)
With 15 years of experience as software engineer, 10 of them as a freelancer, Jerome is now co-founder and CTO at WeWantToKnow. WeWantToKnow is a Norwegian-French startup based in Oslo, Norway and Paris, France, and aim to revolutionize learning. WeWantToKnow are the proud makers of DragonBox Algebra, the multi-award winning app that teaches your kids... algebra!

With 1.5 years experience with Unity and the gaming
industry in general, Jerome will talk about his experience using Unity
in the eye of a non-gaming developer, in particular touching topics
like:

Multi-platform support: how to achieve it Build automation for mobile apps 2D development with Unity Experiences from the life of a startup company The above might be adapted a bit depending on the other speaker's
content and user requests. Please send email to
[masked] if you have specific topics or questions that you would like to be adressed during the talk.

18:15-19:00: Ole Andreas Jordet (Krillbite) - Krillbite, Unity & Kickstarter

Krillbite Studio have existed for only 2 short years. During the development of our bigger upcoming title, Among the Sleep, we have managed to acquire some knowledge regarding being a indie game start-up in Norway, using Unity for bigger game titles and preparing a Kickstarter campaign. These are the main topics I'll talk about.

Ole Andreas is the producer at Krillbite Studio, but also functions as a programmer on this small team of 11 people. With his tech background in server virtualization and technical support he very much enjoys his current position as it involves both technical aspect as well as interacting with fellow humans.
events.how_to_find_us: Note that Acando has moved from Lille Grensen 5 to Tordenskiolds gate 8, and that info in Google Maps is not updated. Here is the correct location: http://bit.ly/14BEZiW

events.name: 2013:05 - Google I/O Extended
events.description:
Experience the magic of Google I/O, right here in Oslo!

Tentative schedule:
17:00-18:00:
Mingling, food and drinks - kindly sponsored by FINN and Google Norway

18:00-21:00:
Live streaming of the Google I/O keynote from Moscone Convention Centre in San Francisco.

 

PS! There will be giveaways/door prizes ;)

events.name: 2013:06 - Android App Clinic + Google I/O Recap
events.description:
17:00-17:45 - Food + drinks + mingling

Kindly sponsored by Making Waves. Also, giveaways sponsored by Sony.

 

17:45- ~19:15 - Android App Clinic with Reto Meier and Ian Ni-Lewis

Every week, professional non-doctors Reto Meier (Tech Lead, Android Developer Relations, Google) and Ian Ni-Lewis (Android Developer Advocate, Google) look at a selection of apps and offer advice and feedback to help app designers and developers create an experience that delights their users.

On June 12th it's our turn, as Reto and Ian takes the Android App Clinic show on the virtual road (via Google Hangout) and visit GDG Oslo. Not sure you're doing the Android interaction patterns quite right? Feel something is a little "off" with your app? Or maybe you just feel like getting some feedback from people working on the Android team? Then this is your chance!

We hope to find time for four app reviews in the App Clinic, where each app maker first present their app for three to five minutes, followed by Reto and Ian spending 10 minutes reviewing the app. To give Reto and Ian some time to prepare their examinations, please submit your app using this form (Registration now closed.) Special giveaways to everyone who submit their app.

Click here for a list of previous App Clinic episodes.

events.name: 2013:09 - Mobile App Dev at FINN.no and Patterns of Large Scale JavaScript Apps
events.description:
17:00-17:30: Mingling + food and drinks  
Kindly sponsored by Miles

17:30-18:30: Kim Joar Bekkelund - Patterns of Large-Scale Javascript Apps
JavaScript has come a long way in few years. As we no longer need to battle DOM differences we can focus on building our applications instead. Now, however, as more and more application logic move from the server to the client our main problem is that we need to unlearn our earlier DOM-centric approach to JavaScript. Tools such as Backbone and Angular help, but before we are able to use them effectively we have to change some of our neural pathways. In this talk I will look at a couple of patterns that will help you move away from jQuery spaghetti and get you started on a foundation for building large-scale JavaScript applications.

18:30-19:30: Alf Thomas Nilsen - Why And How We Do Mobile Native Apps at FINN.no

In this talk Alf Thomas explains why FINN.no develop native mobile applications, what they learned from developing and maintaining their first apps and how they applied that knowledge when developing their next generation native apps.

FINN.no is Norway's biggest classifieds site and nearly half of all visits are from mobile devices. FINN develops native mobile apps for iOS and Android, mobile web and has adopted a mobile first strategy.

This talk will explain why FINN has chosen to develop native mobile applications, and how their architecture enables them to roll out both minor and some major features to all users without requiring a client update.
events.how_to_find_us: Note! Miles' entrance is in the backyard

events.name: 2013:10 Intro to Node.js & SkyLib's Experience with Google App Engine
events.description:
17:00-17:30: Mingling + food and drinks  
Kindly sponsored by Bouvet


17:30-18:30: Claus Sørensen - Where to start with Node.js?
You have probably heard about people writing their server side code in JavaScript. This introduction to node.js will try to explain why that might sometimes be a good idea! And provide you with the tools you need to get started if you want to try it out for yourself.

Claus Asbjørn Sørensen is a partner and senior consultant at Novanet AS, a company focusing on delivering quality and craftsmanship on the Microsoft development stack. In addition to his foundation in the Microsoft and .NET world, Claus is driven by an interest in technology across platforms, especially anything involving development of solutions at web scale.


18:30-19:30: Geir Engdahl - SkyLib's Experiences with Google App Engine
Come and learn why we went with App Engine (Java version) as the backend for SkyLib! Did it work out as expected? What are the major differences between GAE and AWS? What are the gotchas? Hear about some of the APIs we have used, such as the Google Full-text Search API, Google Prediction API, Google Translate API and others.

Geir Engdahl has a master's degree in applied mathematics, a silver medal from the International Olympiad in Informatics and three years experience working for Google in Canada. Recently, he founded SkyLib (skylib.com), where he is CTO. Aside from this, he is active as an organizer of the Norwegian Informatics Olympiad (nio.no) and in the Green Party (MDG).

--

Please note! At recent meetups we have seen that a lot of people have registered for the meetups but haven't showed up. This is unfortunate, as there have been many people on the waiting list who've wanted to attend. For this reason we will start matching the names of those attending to the ones that have registered for the event.
events.how_to_find_us: Take the bus/tram to Torshov. See the map for details.

events.name: 2013:11/2013:12 - What the h#"% is WebRTC and how do I use it?
events.description:
17:00-17:30: Mingling + food and drinks  
Kindly sponsored by Shortcut


17:30-18:30: Dag-Inge Aas/Trond Kjetil Bremnes (Comoyo) - <b style="font-size : 14px">What the h#"% is WebRTC and how do I use it? 

WebRTC (web real-time communication) is one of the hottest buzzwords this year and have been hyped as the future standard of communication services. But few have yet gotten experience with actually working with it. This talk will give you an introduction to what webRTC is, the history behind it, what you can use it for and current challenges with it. 

appear.in is a service for video conversations in the browser that was launched in August, by a team in Telenor Comoyo.  Two of their developers, Dag-Inge Aas and Trond Kjetil Bremnes, will share their experiences with working with a live product that in a short period of time have become one of the leading webRTC-based products. 

--

Please note! At recent meetups we have seen that a lot of people have registered for the meetups but haven't showed up. This is unfortunate, as there have been many people on the waiting list who've wanted to attend. For this reason we will start matching the names of those attending to the ones that have registered for the event.

events.name: 2014:02 - Dart Flight School
events.description:
The event will also be live streamed: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dR8mtQGDukA

--

Hashtags for use in your favorite social media: #flydart and #gdgoslo

--

Agenda:

17:00-17:30

Something to eat and drink, kindly sponsored by Google Norway and KnowIT.

17:30-20:00 - Welcome to the Dart Flight School

Dart is a new web development platform built around a programming language that is unsurprising and familiar, yet powerful and expressive. It comes with libraries for client and server side development, a set of tools that make working on a large Dart application easier, and can be deployed on the modern web via compilation to JavaScript.

During this Dart Flight School we will cover the following facets of the Dart platform:

Dart language and its core libraries

This session gives an introduction to the Dart language and core libraries.


dart2js compiler

Dart-to-JavaScript compilation is an important part of Dart’s deployment story as it allows it to run in any modern browser. This session goes into the details of how the dart2js compiler achieves good performance and output size.

Polymer.dart

Dart strives to fully leverage the evolving web platform on modern browsers. This session presents the Polymer.dart framework which enables building structured, encapsulated, client-side web apps with Dart and web components.

Dart VM

Dart was designed to provide an unsurprising and stable performance. This talk describes native Dart Virtual Machine and how our experience with the V8 JavaScript Engine influenced both language design and the Dart VM implementation.

Speaker Bios:

Vyacheslav Egorov (http://mrale.ph) is a software engineer at Google. He is primarily focused on the technology behind virtual machines and compilers, working first on V8 JavaScript engine and later on the Dart VM. Before joining Google he worked on a Java VM with an ahead-of-time compiler at Excelsior LLC.

Florian Loitsch is a software engineer at Google. He was part of the team that designed the language and the core libraries. Recently he became the tech lead of the dart2js team.

Before Google he worked on compiling Scheme to JavaScript.

events.name: 2014:05 How to design and manufacture an Android smartphone from scratch?
events.description:
18:00-19:00: Food + drinks

Kindly sponsored by BARTEC PIXAVI

18:00-19:00: How to design and manufacture an Android smartphone from scratch? 

BARTEC PIXAVI have developed the world's first intrinsically safe smartphone for use in hazardous areas, the Impact X, a mobile device management system system named Hostedmobiles.com, and the world's first HD video conferencing app for Android, named SIPIDO. 

This presentation will give some technical insight into their experiences in creating an Android device and software for it.

events.name: 2014:10 An Introduction to Go Programming
events.description:
The October GDG meetup will feature an introduction to Go programming. 

Agenda:

17:00-17:30 Food and mingling

Food kindly sponsored by Shortcut


17:30-~18:15 Introduction to Go

Marius Mathiesen will give a brief introduction to the language's core features and strengths. 


~18:30-19:15 Go in the real world

Thomas Kjeldahl Nilsson will walk us through a real-world example of developing a simple REST backend via Go.

events.name: 2014:11/12 GDG DevFest 2014
events.description:
Think of DevFest as a mini conference, where several product areas are covered. Couple this with food, drinks, giveaways and door prizes, and we are sure you will have a memorable evening.

There will be talks on Chrome Dev Tools for mobile development, Docker, Polymer and design and development for Android Wear. See below for complete abstracts. Times may be subject to change.

Agenda:
------------------------------------------------------

17:00-17:45 Streamline Your Development Process With Docker 
Trond Marius Øvstetun (Mesan) 

Most systems we develop today are organized as smaller services or modules that interact with each other. Managing the dependencies between modules and setting up a complete environment is hard and growing harder by the number of modules. This talk will give an introduction to Docker and show how keeping all modules as self-contained Docker-containers helps managing these dependencies. A complete workflow showing how I implement and share a change across modules will be showcased, running from my laptop to my production environment in the Google Cloud Platform. 

Trond Marius works as CTO and Principal Consultant at Mesan. He is on a constant lookout for ways to simplify everyday life, both for developers and operations. Trond Marius has a broad experience developing and running systems using primarily Java, Scala and Clojure - both with and without the use of Docker. 

17:45-18:30 Using Chrome DevTools To Adapt Apps For Smaller Screens 
Trond Kjetil Bremnes (appear.in)

TK from appear.in is going to share some of their learnings from shrinking their existing web application, reworking it to fit smaller handheld screens. In this talk, we'll explore some of the lesser known treasures in Chrome DevTools. Whether you are just starting on developing an app for small screens or are adapting your existing app to smaller screens, we'll show you how Chrome DevTools can aid you in your quest.

Android user, web idealist, pragmatist, TK is a front end developer for appear.in. For the time being, working on mobilizing their web client. 

18:30-19:15 Web Components and Polymer 
Thomas Bassetto (Soundrop)

From <a> to <select>, elements are the building blocks of the web. But modern applications have outgrown these built-in elements, forcing app developers to rely on JavaScript frameworks to provide dynamic, custom behavior. The resulting apps are frequently complex and monolithic; a component developed for one may not work in another. In this talk we'll take a look at the Web Components specs as well as Polymer, a new library that allows developers to create their own HTML elements and compose them into complete applications today.

Thomas is a Software Engineer at Soundrop. He previously worked for several startups in Paris where he designed apps for desktop and TV using web technologies as well as a somewhat successful HTML5 operating system for netbooks.

19:15-19:45 Food
 Food and drinks, kindly sponsored by Mesan

19:45-20:15 Designing for Android Wear
John-Eivind Hallen (Shortcut)

Abstract TBA

20:15-20:45 Developing for Android Wear
Thomas Oldervoll (Zenior) 

This talk will show you how to build an Android Wear app. Thomas will start out with a plain notification and show you how to add features until you have a full-fledged card UI. We will discuss the role of the phone and the watch and how to communicate between them. As a case study he will use a prototype for a news alert app he's working on - there will be plenty of code examples and demos.

Thomas Oldervoll has worked 5 years for Google in Mountain View and 9 years for Zenior in Oslo. He likes building things, in particular machine learning, scalable backend systems and Android apps.

events.name: 2014:04 The Making of NRK's New App
events.description:
The next step in NRKs mobile strategy has been realized. We have made a new mobile release of two of the most popular products in NRK, TV and Super, going from HTML5 to native mobile applications. With over a million users combined, funded by the people and with a widely spread demographic, this is quite a different  challenge than many other projects. 

The presentation will take you with on our journey from idea to released product and beyond, with insight into how we manage  the project process, why we constructed a mobile backend, what architecture and technology we use, how we do testing, and of course a good deal challenges and brick walls we had to overcome. We'll even present a new upcoming feature in the NRK TV app, and sharing some thoughts for the future.

events.name: Google I/O Extended 2015
events.description:

events.name: 2015:05 Google I/O Extended 2015
events.description: Welcome to I/O Extended 2015! Meet other community members to watch the live stream from the Google IO keynote in Moscone and discuss this year's highlights from Google I/O.

events.name: Android 101 training workshop with BEKK
events.description:
Want to learn more about Android development, but don't know where to start? 

Then this training workshop, held by BEKK,  is for you. 

You will be given an introduction to several Android components, in addition to network communication, so you will be able to go home and develop applications on your own.

This workshop consists of a theoretical and a practical part. In the practical part you will develop a Twitter-like application that communicates with a RESTful backend.

Pre-requisites: 
- Bring a laptop and a mobile device/install an emulator (we prefer Genymotion). 

- Install Android Studio and the Android SDK. If possible, run a "Hello World" app on a device or emulator, just to make sure everything is up and running.

Oh, and BEKK will sponsor food and something to drink :) (Thanks!)

events.name: 2016:02 Get to know Google Cloud Platform
events.description:
The February GDG meetup will feature Google Cloud Platform. 

Agenda:

17:00-17:30 Mingling

17:30-~18:15 

Andreas Heim from Unacast will present how Unacast uses Google Cloud Platform - A journey from a company and technical perspective 

~18:30-19:15 

Attila Babo from Nordcloud will talk about how to use Google Cloud Platform optimally.

events.name: Google Hash Code
events.description:
Think you could come up with a way to optimize Internet coverage for Project Loon balloons? Or how about routing Google Street View cars through Paris?

Step into the shoes of a Google engineer and tackle these types of challenges during Hash Code, a team-based programming competition for students and professionals (18+) across Europe, the Middle East and Africa organized by Google. You pick your team and programming language, we pick a real-life engineering problem to solve. Are you up for the challenge?

More info and RSVP at https://www.facebook.com/events/1298741673476706/

events.name: Introduction to Docker and Kubernetes
events.description:
17:00 Introduction to Docker

You probably have heard about Docker before, an open platform for distributed applications for developers and sysadmins. It is used by many small to big players in the tech industry, and serves as a base for its Container Engine. The first talk will thus be an introduction to Docker, by Stéphane Erbrech.

About Stéphane

Stéphane is a software developer and consultant at Webstep. He likes everything Agile, Architecture, Distributed Systems, .Net, Docker, ...

17:45 Pizza break

18:00 Introduction to Kubernetes

Kubernetes helps you manage a cluster of Linux containers as a single system to accelerate Dev and simplify Ops. Google uses it as a foundation for their Container Engine platform. This talk will be an introduction to Kubernetes by Vincent Ambo.

About Vincent

Vincent is ‎a Cloud Architect at Nordcloud. He likes Emacs, spaceships and types.

Many thanks to Webstep for sponsoring the food and to Bouvet for sponsoring video-recording!

events.name: Google Cloud Platform NEXT Live Streaming: App Development
events.description:
Dear developers! 

This event is a collaboration between GDG Oslo and Mobile Meetup Oslo. More info and RSVP at Mobile Meetup Oslo event

Let's meet and get some pizza while watching live video stream of Opening Keynote and a first session from GCPNext'16 - Google Cloud Platform Global User Conference. We'll join the largest gathering of the Google Cloud Platform community to explore the latest developments in cloud technology.

====================

Program

17:00 - 18:30 
NEXT KEYNOTE: DAY 1 WELCOME 

18:30 - 19:00 
Break. Google will provide us with pizza, drinks and probably some SWAG :) 

19:00 - 19:45 
From idea to market in less than 6 months: creating a new product with GCP 
by Daniel Viveiros (GCP GDE), Head of Technology, CI&T

Start-ups and big enterprises alike have a common challenge: ideas cannot wait for years to become a digital product capable of scaling with unpredictable demand. Speed is key, but so is making the right architectural decisions from the beginning. The goal should be preserving initial investments while guaranteeing product robustness. In this session we'll show how the Google Cloud Platform can help companies of all sizes to move quickly and to make the right decisions when creating and developing a new digital product.

=================== 

We have a limited number of seats in amazing Forskningsparken Cinema, so don't wait for too long with your RSVP and please do not forget to update your status if you changed your mind for people in waitlist have a chance to visit us. 

See you in Forskningsparken!

events.name: Fastlane for Android, Realm mobile database and building for reusability
events.description:
This event is co-organized with Mobile Meetup Oslo and embraces its "App Devs Eve #4" event.

Introduction to fastlane for Android

fastlane is the most popular Continuous Delivery solution for iOS apps and it has recently been released for Android too. It lets you define and run your deployment pipelines for different environments and it helps you unify your apps release process and automate the whole process.

This talk will be done by Jerome Lacoste, fastlane contributor, who currently work at http://WeWantToKnow.com where he revolutionises math education through gaming.

Feedback on Realm

Realm is an open source non-sql database for mobile device platforms. Along with the productivity, it brought us pitfalls as well.

This talk will be done by Chang Xiangzhong.

Building for reusability

How do you design and implement an app that needs a lot of customizable and reusable components for different customers? This is a brief walkthrough of our experience with making a massively module-based app, from preliminary design to launched product.

This talk will be done by Espen Almdahl.

events.name: Get Started With Android: Three-night course
events.description:
We are doing another Android training course for beginners, this time across three evenings in April and May: April 20 and 21st, and May 10th.

OUTLINE

The aim is to get you up and running with the basics of Android app development.

We will give you a broad overview first, in order to give you some context. 

Then we'll present the most important building blocks you'll need, and help you apply them using self-contained, tiny tasks. On the final evening we'll hack on a single app the whole time (either your own or one provided by us).

Topics include app lifecycle and environment, basic app screens/layouts and how to move between them, persistence and network communication, as well as the major things that are different in native app development compared to, say, web or backend development.

We will briefly touch on some best practices and tell you where to look for more advanced material/topics. However: the focus is, above all else, to get you started and to provide you with a solid, basic foundation to build on.

COURSE EVENINGS:

Day 1 (April 20)[masked]: Android environment overview. We start looking at basic building blocks like layouts and persistence. A few minor workshop assignments will be provided as we go along.

Day 2 (April 21)[masked]: Continuing from the night before, we give you a few more building blocks including network communication, and focus more on solving workshop assignments together.

Day 3 (May 10)[masked]: Brief recap of material from April

Rest of evening: APP HACKATHON! Bring your own idea and use this night to get a flying start: we'll help you as best we can. OR: work on a predefined fun app idea provided by us. 

PREREQUISITES

•  You should be comfortable with Java programming, or programming in a similar language. 

• We will ask you to install the basic Android Studio development environment (and verify that you can deploy a Hello World app to your phone) before the first course evening. This is to ensure that we don't waste time during the training course.

• We request that you please update your RSVP if you cannot make it. We will have a limited number of seats for this, since active teaching scales to a lower number of attendees than a basic lecture does.

The course will be held in English. It will not be recorded or streamed. We hope to serve food and beverages - currently working on it. :)

events.name: Progressive Web Apps Party
events.description:
This event is co-organized with Framsia, register on their Progressive Web Apps Party event page.

Progressive Web Apps were all the rage at Google I/O! Let's meet early June to learn more about them.

events.name: Simplifying AngularJS in 60 minutes @ FREE
events.description:
FREE AngularJS  Quick Start Webinar

It's a skill that will put you more in demand in the modern web development industry, and make your web software life easier, that's why it's so popular and backed by Google. 

This promises to be an extremely enriching session and we hope you can make it - Register Now

If you require any further information, feel free to contact us on "[masked]" or mail us on Cheers.!

events.name: Everything You Need to Know About Working with "5 Critical Commands in Hadoop"
events.description:

events.name: Mobile/Web App Development Tools
events.description:
The event is co-organized with Mobile Meetup Oslo.

RSVP on their page!

====

Agenda

17:30
Mlab – how we developed a component based app builder for non-developers
by Arild Bergh (Senior Researcher) & Cecilie Jackbo Gran (Senior Engineer). Sinett 3.0 programme at Norwegian Defence Research Establishment (FFI)

Following the disruptive change from desktop to mobile computing there is a large, pent up demand for custom/internal apps in many large organisations. A key problem for these organisations is the clash between the need for advanced apps and the possibilities for non-developers internally in the organisation to create such apps. Complex apps requires professional programmers (increasing time and cost) whereas current non-developer tools usually result in rather basic apps.

To allow non-developers to create advanced apps the Norwegian Defence Research Establishment developed an app builder called Mlab based on re-usable components. The goal was that anyone who knew how to use PowerPoint could create advanced apps through the use of self-contained, interactive components without any programming knowledge.

This presentation will discuss how HTML5/JS/CSS enabled the development of the extensible Mlab framework through components. In particular we will examine how our solutions make both the development (by programmers) and use (by app creators) of components quick and simple without sacrificing power. Mlab was initially created for the Norwegian Defence but will soon be generally available.

18:00
Expect the Unexpected: How to Deal with Errors in JavaScript Applications (Angular, React, Vue, Ionic, etc)
by Mats Bryntse, Chief JavaScript Officer at Bryntum, Sweden

Dealing with unexpected exceptions on the server side is something we've all done for ages. Now it's time to apply the same quality goals and monitoring to our JS codebase. This is especially important for large complex web or mobile applications where the front-end usually contains 100k+ lines of code. I'll demonstrate various powerful monitoring techniques and tricks that we are using ourselves at Bryntum.

events.name: Google Hash Code
events.description:
Hash Code is a team-based programming competition organized by Google for students and industry professionals across Europe, the Middle East and Africa. You pick your team and programming language, we pick a real-life engineering problem for you to solve. Are you up for the challenge?

The competition takes place over two rounds:
Thursday, 23rd February 2017
18:30 to 22:30 CET
> Online Qualification Round. Your team can participate from one of our competition hubs or from wherever else you’d like.
Note:
GDG Oslo, StartUiO and StartupLab is organizing a hub in Oslo. You can choose your hub when you register your team at https://hashcode.withgoogle.com/ Saturday, 1st April 2017
9:30 to 21:30 CET
> Final Round. Top scoring teams from the Online Qualification Round will be invited to Google Paris to compete in the Final Round of the competition.

Registration is already opened here:
https://events.withgoogle.com/hashcode2017-signup/registrations/new/details/

events.name: Cloud Next ‘17 Extended
events.description:
Next ‘17 will be the largest event in Google’s history. Google Cloud engineers, customers and partners will gather for inspiration and hands on experiences with tools, technologies and services born in the Cloud, including the latest developments from Google Cloud Platform, G Suite, Maps and Devices.

You don’t have to be in San Francisco to be part of history! GDG Oslo is bringing the community together at Google Norway to experience talks, quizzes and view the opening keynote live.

• 17:00: Food will be served
• 17:30: Quiz with prizes
• 17:35: "Machine Learning at NRK, on Google Cloud", by Thomas Oldervoll from Zenior
• 18:00: Livestream
• 19:30: Mingling

Join us to learn from experts and engage with peers!

events.name: Android meetup - Security and more
events.description:
We are happy to invite you to Android meetup.
Agenda:

17:30  Secure your Android application - secure storage and communication  - by Thomas Pettersen

It's so easy to download an app and extract "protected" details from it, that anyone can do it. We do not want some 14 year old kid posting sensitive info from our apps on youtube... To better safeguard our data, communications and hashing algorithms, we need to be able to hack our own apps and see what we are exposing. Then we can learn to protect them. This talk will demonstrate how to hack apps, which methods of safeguarding that is effective and discuss problems we might encounter when dealing with security.

18:20 Hidden Android features - by Konstantin Loginov

Android is everywhere now: in your TV, in your car, on your wrist, in your pocket. Every year Google ships dozens of new features for Android and it's getting almost impossible to keep track of all of them and even harder to allocate time to experiment with them. However, going this extra mile, you can enrich your customers' experience, uncover new horizontals or bump up your chances to be featured.
In this talk I'll cover some of the features which are not particularly mainstream nowadays but probably deserve your closer look, such as Google Play Campaign Measurement, Shortcuts and many more.

events.name: Serverless with Google Cloud and Firebase
events.description:
This meetup is co-organized with Serverless Oslo. Please RSVP on their page: https://www.meetup.com/Serverless-Oslo/events/240246512/.

---------------

Bret will demo and live code some of the serverless products from Google Cloud, including Firebase and Google Cloud Functions. 

Google Cloud Functions is Functions as a Service (FaaS) and Firebase is an entire Backend-as-a-Service (BaaS); 

Bret will show you how you can combine these to create entire web and mobile applications without managing servers.

Bret McGowen is a Developer Advocate at Google.

Twitter: @bretmcg.

events.name: The Big Golang Meetup
events.description:
This is the meetup that programmers who are interested in the high performance, scalable, lightweight, cross platform language that do not compromise with ease of programming, agility and fun have been waiting for. You are talking about Go of course!

17:30

Food served by our sponsor, Kodemaker.

18:00

From zero to 400 webhooks/second in 24 hours, by Ernesto Jimenez (Google Developer Expert)

We'll talk about how we prototyped a service to dispatch webhooks leveraging Go, Kubernetes, Prometheus and Google Cloud Platform in a company hackathon.  We'll go through our objectives, the design, the results, and some of the challenges we found along the way.

19:00

Using Go at capsule.fm by Tor Langballe (CTO)

This is a talk will focus on the the experience gained from building a fairly large project in Go. We'll see why we chose Go, how we dealt with external code usage, database programming APIs and web interfaces. Finally we will see which changes we wish to see for the next version of the language.

20:00

Drawing of a free ticket to dotGo.eu, thanks to our sponsor dotConferences.
events.how_to_find_us: Find us on the top floor. When your enter the building, go straight ahead to the staircase and then to the top!

events.name: Bigtable for Time Series Database & Chrome Dev Summit Keynote Livestream
events.description:
Warm welcome to our meetup!

18:00

Using Bigtable for a Large-Scale Industrial IoT Time Series Database

Geir Engdahl, Cognite

The amount of internet connected sensors is exploding, and so is the data they are generating. A modern oil rig produces roughly 100 thousand different time series. Some at sub-second resolution. At Cognite, we want to store the full operational history of industrial machinery, so that it can be used to investigate problems, optimize future production and energy use, and train models that will predict failures. This talk focuses on how we use Google's petabyte-scale Bigtable key-value storage system to accomplish efficient storage and fast lookups on this data.

19:00

Chrome Dev Summit 2017 Keynote Livestream!

Hear the keynote address by Ben Galbraith, who will present an overview of the state of Chrome and the Web Platform today.

events.name: [External] Cloud OnBoard | Training in Oslo
events.description:
GDG Oslo is not hosting this event, Google is.

This Meetup event used as a placeholder to spread the news about the Google's event. Please accept our sincere apologies as it has caused some confusion.

// Cloud OnBoard - Oslo is a free full-day instructor-led enablement and training event that will provide you with a step-by-step technical introduction to the Google Cloud Platform (GCP). Through a combination of instructor-led presentations and technical demonstrations, you will learn how to get started with Google App Engine, Datastore, Storage, Container Engine, Compute Engine and Network, Big Data and Machine Learning.

Cloud OnBoard has been designed for IT Managers, Systems Engineers and Operations professionals, Developers, Solution Architects and modern business leaders who are exploring cloud solutions or are new to Google Cloud Platform. Leveraging the GCP Fundamentals course, the event will provide you with the technical training you need to get started as well as access to tips and tricks, industry best-practice and questions and answers from the GCP team.

Please sign up using the below external link.

https://lp.google-mkto.com/2017-OnBoard-Oslo

events.name: Conversational UI Principles and Extending the Google Assistant
events.description:
We’re entering a promising new era of computing, where advances in machine learning and artificial intelligence are creating a resurgence of interest in conversational interfaces and natural language processing, creating the potential for conversation as the new mode of interaction with technology.

Join us for the following talks by Thomas Bassetto, Software Engineer at Cisco and Google Developer Expert on Web Technologies, and by Vidar Falkenberg, Customer Engineer at Google:

• An introduction to conversational UI principles and what makes a good conversation.

• An overview of the creation of apps extending the Google Assistant using Actions on Google (https://developers.google.com/actions/), letting users get things done with your products and services.

• Building Conversational Chatbots with Dialogflow and Google Cloud Platform

Food will be served at 18:00.

A little elf told us that Christmas will be early this year and that there will be a draw to win a Google AIY Voice Kit ;)

events.name: Cloud Study Jam
events.description:
Want to get started on the Google Cloud, but don't know where to begin?

Join us for our Cloud Study Jam! Together we'll work through three Google Cloud Platform Essentials labs, then you will get free access to the next quest so you can finish this series of labs at home to get a Google-hosted badge for your online profile. You will be able to get hands-on experience with Docker and Kubernetes, which will earn you additional badges.

Join this meetup to get official Google training, free of charge.

Bring a laptop with the latest versions of the popular Internet browsers installed. For the best experience, make sure your laptop has Firefox or Chrome installed.

Everyone who attends the Study Jam gets a free 1-month pass to Qwiklabs. If Cloud Study Jam attendees earn the GCP Essentials badge within that first month, they will get another free 1-month pass to use any way they choose. Those who have earned the GCP Essentials badge within the first month will receive extra second campaign link with an additional 30-days pass benefit.

Google Norway will be sponsoring the food and drinks for the evening.

We want to support you to complete Google Cloud Essentials, join our Slack ﻿workspace﻿. Ask questions on `#cloud` channel.

Agenda:

17:00 : Three Google Cloud Platform Essentials labs:      

* GSP001 - Creating a Virtual Machine

https://qwiklabs.com/focuses/6473      

* GSP003 - Provision Services with Cloud Launcher

https://qwiklabs.com/focuses/6477

* GSP004 - Creating a Persistent Disk (Activity Tracking)

https://qwiklabs.com/focuses/6985

18:30 : Break. Food and drinks sponsored by Google Norway.

19:00 : GSP055 - Introduction to Docker

https://qwiklabs.com/focuses/7042

20:00 : End

events.name: B&B Android Open House
events.description:
**** Please RSVP on https://www.facebook.com/events/1613898328723418/ Thank you :) ****

Come one, come all to the fabulous Bakken & Bæck Android Open House in collaboration with GDG Oslo.

We have a great line-up of two seasoned speakers both currently residing in the Netherlands..

Annyce Davis (@brwngrldev) is a Google Developer Expert, conference speaker, instructor, and Android developer. She currently works at Off Grid Electric, a social impact startup that provides clean, transformative energy to households that suffer from expensive, unreliable grids or have no grid access at all.

Annyce will be talking about getting to grips with GraphQL; a query language for your API. We'll learn about what GraphQL is all about and how we can take advantage of it in our applications.

Ellen Shapiro (@designatednerd) is an iOS and Android developer at Bakken & Bæck's Amsterdam office. She is currently working on the Ethereum wallet and Dapp browser Toshi. Having experience from both mobile worlds gives Ellen a unique perspective which she is putting to good use as a collaborator on the Ray Wenderlich book "Kotlin Apprentice"

Ellen will be talking about Enum and Sealed classes in Kotlin - extremely powerful ways to deal with a known set of possible values. Learn how to use these tools to help you cleaner, safer code, and how to push the boundaries of what's possible with enums.

Food and drink will be served.

**** Please RSVP on https://www.facebook.com/events/1613898328723418/ Thank you :) ****

events.name: Kotlin på Android = <3
events.description:
*** Note that this Meetup will be held in Norwegian 🇳🇴 and that you should RSVP on the Oslo Kotlin Meetup page ➡️ https://www.meetup.com/meetup-group-nWeRbyMu/events/251123351/ ***

Description from https://www.meetup.com/meetup-group-nWeRbyMu/events/251123351/:

Hei alle sammen! Nå er det tid for den første Kotlin-meetupen, og det er bare å glede seg. I dag skal vi høre Thomas Pettersen snakke om hvor mye Kotlin forenkler livet vårt når det gjelder utvikling for Android. Det blir lett servering med pizza og brus, og muligheter til mingling og diskusjoner etter foredraget.

17. mai 2017 kunngjorde Google at Kotlin var offisielt støttet i Android. "Hurra!" tenkte vi utviklere, da vi endelig fikk et moderne alternativ til Java. I ettertid har det også kommet flere extensions til Kotlin på Android som har gjort livet svært mye enklere. Siden mai i fjor har han jobbet med apper hvor det har blitt tatt i bruk Kotlin, som Yr og Nabohjelp, og denne talken tar for seg erfaringene i praksis med utvikling av Android-apper i Kotlin. Livet BLIR lettere :D

Om foredragsholderen:
Thomas er en meteorologiutdannet programmeringsnerd med mobilt DNA og lidenskap for alt fra IoT til innovasjon. Han har jobbet med Android i Mesan og Netcompany siden 2010 med apper som NRK TV, Yr, Nabohjelp og KvoteAppen. Alltid mye på hjertet som han deler villig vekk!

Denne meetupen sponses av Systek og Evry.

*** Note that this Meetup will be held in Norwegian 🇳🇴 and that you should RSVP on the Oslo Kotlin Meetup page ➡️ https://www.meetup.com/meetup-group-nWeRbyMu/events/251123351/ ***

events.name: Firebase Codelabs: Cloud Firestore and Cloud Functions
events.description:
We are excited to have Susan from the Firebase team visiting Oslo.

Susan will lead a codelab where we build an application with Firebase using Cloud Firestore and Cloud Functions.

Abstract:

When you build an app using Firebase, it takes care of data storage, synchronization, file storage, authentication, and other backend functionalities so that your time is spent polishing user interactions. In this codelab you will build a Firestore-backend restaurant recommendation web app.

You will learn how to:
* Read and write data to Firestore from a web app.
* Listen to changes in Firestore data in real-time.
* Use Firebase Authentication and security rules to secure Firestore data.
* Write complex Firestore queries.
* Integrate with Cloud Functions.

Note:

Power sockets are limited. Please bring an extra power strip if needed.

If you are working for companies or startups who are using extensively any Firebase product, please contact the Meetup organizer as we have save few seats for you.

Instructor(s):

Susan Goldblatt is a Software Engineer at Google. She works on Firebase as a front end developer. Before Google, she wrote a computer science curriculum for high schoolers and worked at a startup in NYC.

events.name: Before the summer: Google Maps and Flutter
events.description:
Details
Warm welcome to our meetup!

17:20

Intro to Google Maps Platform

Alex Muramoto, Developer Advocate for Geo @ Google

Love Google Maps? Want to build awesome geo experiences? Of course you do! In this talk we’ll give an overview of Google Maps Platform, it’s APIs/SDKs, data coverage, and feature set. We’ll also look at an example of using the Deck.gl framework to build awesome data visualizations with WebGL and the Maps JS API.

18:00

Cross Platform Mobile Development using Flutter

Wei-Meng Lee, Technologist & Founder @ Developer Learning Solutions

Maintaining multiple code bases for the same application is often a pain in the neck for mobile developers. In the recent years, different frameworks have appeared in the market that aim to reduce the workload of developers by offering them a write-once-run-everywhere approach. In this session, we will take a quick look at the different frameworks available - Xamarin, React Native, and Flutter. We will focus on using Flutter and see how it makes your life as a mobile developer easier. At the end of the session, we will build a news reader application using Flutter.

events.name: Kotlin/Everywhere Oslo
events.description:
Want to get started with Kotlin, but don't know where to begin? Join us for our Kotlin/Everywhere event.

During this evening we will have an introduction talk about Kotlin, followed by a talk about Kotlin coroutines. Then you will get hands-on experience with Kotlin while working through several Android / Google Cloud / multi-platform codelabs.

Bring a laptop (PC, Mac or Chromebook). The labs will run on all of the latest versions of the popular browsers. For the best experience, make sure your laptop has Chrome or Firefox installed. Don’t forget your charger!

Tentative agenda:

17:00 Welcome
17:30 Introduction to Kotlin with Trym Nilsen

How can you start using Kotlin today and what should you be aware of if you want to learn Kotlin?
In this introduction to Kotlin we will have a look at which new features Kotlin brings to the table, and which best practices you might consider using by showing hands-on examples and snippets.
If you have experience from other programming languages, you also will see how this knowledge transfers to Kotlin.

18:15 Kotlin coroutines - Thomas Pettersen

Asynchronism and threading can be quite cumbersome to deal with in programming. Kotlin (re)introduces a concept known as coroutines, making concurrency easy to both read and write in addition to speeding up performance. This presentation will guide you through the basics of coroutines, compare it to other concurrency models out there, and even show how to test these asynchronous structures. This might be an eye opener to solve many of your future problems.

19:00 Break
19:20 Codelabs
21:00 Event ends

events.name: Build and scale serverless mobile apps with Firebase and Google Cloud
events.description:
If your app has millions of users, you need a backend infrastructure to support its growth. Do you want to build that infrastructure? Of course not! Your time is better spent focusing on the app. In this talk, we'll take a look at the code for a mobile app that works like a “universal translator”. It uses Firebase and Google Cloud services and APIs. And we'll do it "serverless" without having to manage servers or infrastructure. A live demo of the app will be done with audience participation - bring a phone or laptop!

Doug Stevenson is a veteran engineer, experienced public speaker, and developer advocate at Google with the Firebase team. He developed web apps before the web had "apps", and developed for Android since the very first Android device was on the market. In the SF bay area, he's bootstrapped the efforts of several startups. Outside of work, Doug follows professional ice hockey and enjoys craft beer.

Entrance door closes at 17:45. Please be punctual.

events.name: Cloud Study Jam: Kubernetes

https://www.meetup.com/GDG-Cloud-Norway/events/268108412/

Please RSVP using the above link.

events.name: Collaborative Virtual Event - Progressive Web Apps Evening
events.description:
We are excited to announce our PWA evening talks, a virtual event by GDG Oslo, GDG Bergen, GDG Sorlandet and GDG Stavanger collaboration.

Link to watch the meetup: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iTqbZF71Law

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

1. Taking your web app offline (in a good sense)
Speaker: Maxim Salnikov - Microsoft
Description:
Web as an application platform is amazing: evergreen browsers or some form of web views exist almost on every device with UI, we have native APIs to access the hardware, we use versatile language with the excellent tooling, we are the huge (the largest ever) developer community after all! But the web historically tightly coupled with the connection state... In my session, we confirm: the modern web APIs and some best practices allow us to build offline-first web apps: always available, caring about data consumption, preserving and sync, providing UX which is comparable (if not better) to the native apps, regardless of the connection. Plus, the current state of the tooling makes it possible to add these features in a fast and reliable way. Let's explore the offline web in a very practical manner - by building the offline-first app!

This session will be useful for web front-end developers who have heard about progressive web apps (who haven't :), maybe even tired of PWA-hype, and thus want to understand some of UX benefits on practice. As this is not another "What is PWA" session, I focus exclusively on the modern APIs making offline-first approach possible, in a form of task+solution sections - to maximize the usefulness.

Backend developers and mobile developers will get a nice overview of what web can do today (they will be impressed).

2. Make your app installable
Speaker: Laura Morinigo - Samsung Internet
Description:
A progressive web app is a way to bring a native-app experience into the browser. One of the main features is the ability to make your app installable on different platforms like desktop and smartphones. During this talk, we are going to review what we need to make our app installable, the best practices and standards that we have to follow in order to bring a good user experience, trends and a reference to the manifest file.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

About our speakers:

Maxim Salnikov:

This time we are so lucky to be joined by Maxim Salnikov from Microsoft.
Maxim Salnikov is an Oslo-based cloud and web front-end geek with a strong passion for the developer community building. He architects and builds complex web applications since the end of the last century, and has extensive experience with all aspects of web platform focusing on the apps managing real-time data from IoT devices, and Progressive Web Apps. He is a Google Developer Expert in Web Technologies & IoT, and a former Microsoft MVP in Development Technologies.

Maxim is a founder and active contributor to two conferences: Mobile Era and ngVikings - Nordics’ main conferences for mobile and Angular developers respectively. Also, he leads Norway’s largest meetups dedicated to web front-end and mobile: Angular Oslo, Mobile Meetup, Oslo PWA, Framsia.

Maxim is passionate about sharing his web platform experience and knowledge with the community. He travels extensively for visiting developers events and speaking/training at conferences and meetups around the world.

Laura Morinigo:
Laura is a senior software developer, advocate, and mentor. Her enthusiasm for technology and communities made her recognized as a Google Developer Expert and a Woman Techmakers Ambassador. Currently, she is a web developer advocate for Samsung Internet where she contributes to spread the word about advanced web features, especially PWA, helping web developers to create great and more inclusive web apps.

upcoming.name: Online Firebase Study Jam
upcoming.description:
This meetup will be held online only.

The previous in-person Meetup will _not_ be held as one of our proactive measures to contain the spread of Coronavirus disease (COVID-19).

Join a community of like-minded developers and explore the latest Firebase for Web technologies as a team.

Want to get started building web apps? Learn how to do that with Firebase!

Join us for our Firebase Study Jam! Together we'll work through Firebase for web codelabs prepared by Google instructors. You will be able to get hands-on experience with Firebase.

Use your own laptop and charger (PC, Mac or Chromebook)! The labs will run on all of the latest versions of popular browsers.

Agenda:

16:45 Introduction to Firebase
17:00 Codelab: Get to know Firebase for Web (https://google.dev/codelabs/firebase-get-to-know-web)
18:00 Codelab: Get know Cloud Firestore (https://google.dev/pathways/firebase-firestore)
19:00 Codelab: Getting started with the Firebase Local Emulator Suite (https://google.dev/pathways/firebase-emulators)
19:30 Codelab: Add new functionality to your web app quickly with Firebase Extensions (https://google.dev/codelabs/firebase-extensions)
20:00 End

Optional:

You are invited to join the Google Groups for Firebase Study Jam. Joining this group[1] will whitelist your email address and grant you access to create a Google.dev account. Please allow ~ 15 min to request go through.

[1] https://groups.google.com/forum/m/#!forum/firebase-study-jam

Google.dev allows attendees to create a developer profile and save their progress within a codelab.

If you decide not to join the Google group, you will still have access to all codelabs, but won’t be able to create you own account at Google.dev platform.

upcoming.name: Collaborative Virtual Event - Flutter Study Jam
upcoming.description:
We are excited to announce our Flutter Study Jam, a virtual event by Flutter Oslo Meetup Group, GDG Oslo, GDG Bergen, GDG Sørlandet, GDG Stavanger and GDG Trondheim collaboration.

Note: Link to join the event will be announced soon.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Join us for our Online Flutter Study Jam!

Flutter is Google’s portable UI kit for crafting high-quality native interfaces on iOS and Android in record time. Flutter works with existing code, is used by developers and organizations around the world, and is free and open source.

Together we'll work through Flutter codelabs prepared by Google instructors. You will be able to get hands-on experience with Flutter and build an app while learning the fundamentals.

The Study Jams for Flutter is best suited for two audiences:

1) Those with programming experience who have never used flutter and want to see what’s it all about.

2) People who have some experience with Flutter and want to learn new ways to implement mobile/web apps in.

IMPORTANT INFO:
Prepare a laptop! For the best experience, the laptop should have Flutter installed on it prior to starting the study jam to save time. Windows/Linux/Mac would all be fine.

Please check if after installing Flutter SDK your laptop can compile and run a basic empty app in Flutter.

Check out: https://flutter.dev/docs/get-started/install

Please install Visual Studio Code if you don't have Android Studio already set up
How to install VsCode: https://flutter.dev/docs/development/tools/vs-code

Windows setup: https://flutter.dev/docs/get-started/install/windows
Mac setup: https://flutter.dev/docs/get-started/install/macos
Linux setup: https://flutter.dev/docs/get-started/install/linux

Agenda:
17:00 - Welcome talk
17:15 - Start
20:00/20:30 - End

About Instructors:

Muhammed Salih Guler:

Salih is a Berlin-based Senior Mobile Engineer who is a Google Developer Expert for Flutter and Dart. He likes sharing his knowledge with the people by mentoring aspiring developers, blogging and talking at conferences.

Majid Hajian:

Majid is a passionate software developer with years of developing and architecting complex web and mobile applications. He is passionate about web platform especially Flutter, IoT, PWAs, and performance. He loves sharing his knowledge with the community by writing and speaking, contributing to open source and organizing meetups and events. Majid is the award-winning author of "Progressive web app with Angular" book by Apress and "Progressive Web Apps" video course by PacktPub and Udemy. He is (co)organizer of a few mobile and web meetups in Norway as well as Nordic conferences for mobile and Angular, Mobile Era and ngVikings.

upcoming.name: Collaborative virtual event: Angular evening with 3 great sessions
upcoming.description:
We are excited to announce our Angular evening talks! a virtual event by Angular Oslo, Angular Stavanger and GDG Oslo, GDG Bergen, GDG Sørlandet, GDG Stavanger and GDG Trondheim collaboration

The link to watch will be announced soon.

----
Title:
The future of Angular and Ivy by Manfred Steyer

Abstract:
Ivy is primarily associated with smaller bundles and therefore better performance. However, Ivy has much more to offer, and many smart concepts provide the foundation for some much-anticipated future features.

Find out how Ivy's potential can impact your future architecture. We use a case study to explore a possible future without NgModules but Standalone Components, the use of dynamic components or higher-order components, zone-less change detection, and new possibilities for lazy loading and plug-in systems.

In the end, you understand Ivy's potential and how to start preparing for it today.

------------------------

Title: TBD by Fabriece Sumuni
Abstract: TBD

------------------------

Title: Angular Elements for Authentication: The what, the how and the why by Ana Cidre

Abstract:
In this talk, we will take a look at what Angular Elements are, what they consist of and how to build them. Then we will see what advantages Web Components have when approaching and implementing authentication into our application, how Web Components can facilitate the implementation of authentication and share some examples of which Web Components we can create to simplify the process. We will also talk about what options we have today to build Web Components, which frameworks support them and whether browsers are ready for them.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
Our Speakers' biography:

Manfred Steyer:
Trainer, consultant and programming architect with a focus on Angular. Google Developer Expert (GDE) and Trusted Collaborator in the Angular team who writes for O'Reilly, the German Java Magazine, and windows.developer. He regularly speaks at conferences.

Ana Cidre:
Ana is a Developer Advocate at Auth0. She has a degree in Fine Arts and a Master in International Business Economics and Management, so she is not your usual software developer. She loves to code and she especially likes Angular. As a very active member of the community, she regularly organises meetups and conferences, like the amazing ngSpain. In Spain, where she’s currently based, she’s an organiser of GDG Vigo and the founder of GalsTech, a group for women in tech from Galicia. Because she is so passionate about diversity, she has also been named a Women Techmaker Ambassador.

Fabriece Sumuni:
